div.p: The Extension Definition resource provides a forml definition of an extension used in a FHIR resource, that can used as the basis for validation, and code, report and UI generation.

ul.li: Every extension in a resource refers directly to it's definition
ExtensionDefinitions are used by Profile instances when specifying that extensions are used in a resource

div.p: Whenever resources containing extensions are exchanged, the definitions of the extensions SHALL be available to all the parties that share the resources. Each extension contains a URI that references the source of the definitions as a Resource Profile. The source SHOULD be a literal reference, such as an http: url that refers to an end-point that responds with the contents of the definitions - preferably a FHIR RESTful server supporting the Resources Profile, or a logical reference (e.g. using a urn:) - for instance, to a national published standard.

Extensions may be defined by any project or jurisdiction, up to and including international standards organizations such as HL7 itself. Extensions are always defined against some particular context - the type of element that they may be used to extend. The following are possible contexts for an extension:

tr.td: A particular element (including the root) in a single resource

The element path for that element
Note: If the context is an element that can have multiple types, then use (e.g.) value[x] if the extension works on all choice types, or otherwise an enumeration of explicitly named elements if not
A particular element (including the root) in a particular data type
The data type name for primitive types or the element path for complex data types
A particular context in one of the mapped reference models
The name of the reference model followed by the mapping path
The profile uri of the extension followed by the extension code
A set of some combination of the above

div.p: In addition, an extension definition might apply additional constraints with regards to particular element values of the target that make its use appropriate. Extensions SHALL only be used on a target for which they are defined.
